# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

At https://angular.io/api/router/ExtraOptions, the docs state that `initialNavigation` defaults to `enabled`:

> One of enabled (the default) or disabled.

This is not the case. Looking at the code (https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/router/src/router_module.ts#L556),  it defaults to `legacy_enabled`, which is not the same as `enabled` (e.g. `enabled` is required for SSR to work as per https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/15716#issuecomment-291025332).

The docs do not mention the legacy values as these are deprecated, so I'm not sure what would be the best way to phrase it. Maybe:

> One of enabled or disabled (defaults to a legacy behavior for compatibility).

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description Following the instructions to build the start application locally fails. The deployment page needs additional information about handling different StackBlitz and local environment versions. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - Download start application project from StackBlitz - unzip downloaded file - ng new test-project - rm -rf test-project/src - mv ~/Downloads/tmp/src test-project - ng build --prod ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/start/deployment ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Expected: `ng` builds the project, creating files in the dist folder. Actual: build error messages and abort ## üî• Exception or Error 
ERROR in ./src/polyfills.ts
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'core-js/es6/reflect' in '‚Ä¶/src'
ERROR in ./src/polyfills.ts
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'core-js/es7/reflect' in '‚Ä¶/src'
## üåç Your Environment 5.2.11-200.fc30.x86_64 ng --version ‚Ä¶ Angular CLI: 8.3.1 Node: 10.16.3 OS: linux x64 Angular: ‚Ä¶ @angular-devkit/architect 0.803.1 @angular-devkit/core 8.3.1 @angular-devkit/schematics 8.3.1 @schematics/angular 8.3.1 @schematics/update 0.803.1 rxjs 6.4.0 ### Anything else relevant Researching the cause of the reported missing files found With that hint, I did some version checks. The downloaded package.json shows `"core-js": "2.6.9"` while a new empty local project package-lock.json shows `"core-js": "3.2.1"`. A significant difference. Further checking shows that the StackBlitz project was created with `Angular CLI version (7.0.7)`, while my local environment is `(8.3.1)`. Obviously not directly compatible. After experimenting with ways to get the StackBlitz code updated to the newer environment for awhile, I hit on a simple solution. Before deleting the `/src` folder from the new local project, save a copy of `/src/polyfills.ts`. After moving the downloaded `/src` folder into the project, replace the downloaded `polyfills.ts` file with the saved version. That gets the latest polyfill version, apparently upgrading everything to match the local environment. The `polyfills.ts` file was never touched while creating the start application on StackBlitz. It seems to have the default for the environment used there. So it should be safe to simply replace it. At least it worked for me, with no warnings about version differences.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The `Building locally` section says (abbreviated) to download the project code from StackBlitz, and use it to replace the `/src` folder of an empty local project.  The downloaded zip file includes files `angular.json`, `package.json` and `tsconfig.json` outside of the source folder.  The deployment information should mention them, and what to do with them.  In this case they are ignored and thrown away, but I suspect that information from them will be needed if extra packages have been installed.  Since the zip file contains more than the `/src` folder, need to be a bit more careful just where it is unzipped.  My first attempt unzipped to the root folder for the local angular project, then `ng new ‚Ä¶` failed because it saw the json files, and refused to create a new project in what it saw as an existing project folder.  Including information about the files, and a brief description of what they are used for would avoid confusion.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Download the start application from StackBlitz.  Unzip.  See the actual extracted contents, compared to what the deployment page describes.

### What's the affected URL?**

https://angular.io/start/deployment

`Building locally` second paragraph, mixed with creating a new Angular CLI workspace, and replacing the `/src` folder.

# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Life cycle and Change detection not running in the correct order for 2 sibling components. ### Is this a regression? Not that I'm aware of. ### Description I have 2 sibling components. The first hosts a template via ngTemplateOutlet The 2nd has the template as part of its view to be used by its sibling. The parent gets the template from the 2nd child and passes it to the first child. It works fine if the template that we're getting from the 2nd child gets passed to the 1st child in the first cycle. However, if we need a 2nd cycle to get the template like the following code it doesn't work. 

  ngAfterViewInit() {
    setTimeout(() => {
      this.templates = this.templateQuery.map( c => c.template );
      this.cdr.markForCheck();
    }, 0);
  }
Doing it in the set timeout is necessary otherwise you may get a ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError. The input bindings on the inner template are always one cycle behind the parent component. The issue appears to be that the order that angular runs the life cycle hooks is not the same in the 1st case as in the 2nd. In the first case. The content is checked on the template component before the host component. So the change is detected and passed through to the host component. However in the 2nd case Change detection first runs on the host component and nothing changed yet so the view doesn't update. Then it's run on the template component, but it's already too late for the host component. So it's not picked up till the next cycle. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction click the button and notice the inner template in the broken section is one step behind. https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-djxc1a ## üî• Exception or Error The view isn't updated correctly. The child is one cycle behind the parent. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular CLI: 8.2.2
Node: 12.6.0

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

Some time ago I was researching what triggers `NavigationCancel` because the docs don't mention this information right now (at least not on the [`NavigationCancel`](https://angular.io/api/router/NavigationCancel) page).

Later, I made a [post](https://dzhavat.github.io/2019/06/08/when-is-navigation-cancel-triggered.html) with my findings. In there I mention two cases:

* when a route guard returns `false`
* on redirect initiated by a route guard

These aren't extraordinary findings by any means but I think it might be helpful mentioning them in the docs.

I also volunteer for doing a PR in case this is accepted :)

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**

https://angular.io/api/router/NavigationCancel

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

While going though upgrade guide I stumbled upon [this part](https://angular.io/guide/upgrade#aot-compile-the-hybrid-app) is pointing out to [The Ahead-of-Time (AOT) compiler](https://angular.io/guide/aot-compiler) article which mostly covers usage of `angular-cli` and compiler details. In 99% this won't be a case in hybrid app because they already have own building setup. Upgrade guide also refers to `main-aot.ts` here:
> Then change main-aot.ts to bootstrap the AppComponentFactory that was generated by the AOT compiler

But does newcomer will know what this mean, I don't think so, for me it also wasn't obvious.
This chapter doesn't cover situation, where existing AngularJS app could use `webpack`. Which is quite popular case if you look at the number of angularjs-webpack starter projects.

### What's the affected URL?**
https://angular.io/guide/upgrade#aot-compile-the-hybrid-app
https://angular.io/guide/aot-compiler

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**

I would expect that this chapter will exhaustively cover how to put aot in place into existing project that don't use `angular-cli` just like the others topics in upgrade guide.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:-->

Both 
- [https://angular.io/api/common/formatCurrency](https://angular.io/api/common/formatCurrency) and
- [https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/961d663fbef4d6ea2ebb5a60f38799a273fa71ed/packages/common/src/i18n/format_number.ts#L136-L137](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/961d663fbef4d6ea2ebb5a60f38799a273fa71ed/packages/common/src/i18n/format_number.ts#L136-L137) 
say the `currencyCode` param is the "...currency code to use in the result string...". However, `currencyCode` is in fact not used in the returned string.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

```
// actually returns '$12.34', not something like '$12.34 CAD' as expected by the docs
formatCurrency(12.34, 'en-US', '$', 'CAD');
```

### What's the affected URL?**
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> 
- [https://angular.io/api/common/formatCurrency
](https://angular.io/api/common/formatCurrency)
- [https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/961d663fbef4d6ea2ebb5a60f38799a273fa71ed/packages/common/src/i18n/format_number.ts#L136-L137](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/961d663fbef4d6ea2ebb5a60f38799a273fa71ed/packages/common/src/i18n/format_number.ts#L136-L137)

### Reproduction Steps**
<!-- If applicable please list the steps to take to reproduce the issue -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> 
```
// '$12.34'
console.log(formatCurrency(12.34, 'en-US', '$', 'CAD'));
```

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
<!-- If applicable please describe the difference between the expected and actual behavior after following the repro steps. -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:-->

Either
- the docs for the `currencyCode` param should say "The ISO 4217 currency code such as USD for the US dollar and EUR for the euro. Used to determine the number of digits in the decimal part.";
or
- `formatCurrency` should include the `currencyCode` in its return value.

## Summary ##
Since Angular 6 there have been 2 fundamentally different ways of configuring services for injection but these 2 approaches don't interact well with one another which can result in confusing application bugs, and I don't think the implications of the 2 different approaches have been made sufficiently clear in the documentation.

## Caveat ##
I'm not really sure of the best way to categorise this issue. I think documentation improvements could help users to handle this better, but it really seems to me to be more of a design flaw in the service injection framework. From a coding perspective, I'm not really sure what could be done to improve it, but there may well be a good solution that I've been unable to think of.

Much of this problem has already been touched on by a couple of other github issues:
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10170
- https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/25784

## The Current Situation ##
Prior to Angular 6, services were generally configured for injection by decorating the service's containing NgModule as follows:
```
@NgModule({
    providers: [MyService]
})
export class MyServiceModule {
```
But since Angular 6, users have been encouraged to configure services as follows instead:
```
@Injectable({
    providedIn: 'root'
})
export class MyService {
```

The new approach has 2 advantages, namely:
1.  It enables tree-shaking of unused services - since they no longer have to be included in the `providers` array of an NgModule.
2.  It ensures that only one instance of the service will ever exist - _even if the service is consumed by multiple, lazy-loaded modules_

I think it's worth noting however, that:
1.  Tree-shaking of services is only really necessary when writing a third party library. When writing an _application_ it is pretty unlikely that you would include - except perhaps by accident - a service which you weren't intending to use somewhere.
2.  Service duplication can be avoided anyway by taking appropriate care when lazy-loading modules - although the new approach _is_ safer in this respect.

The new approach also has one very important implication though, which I don't think is made sufficiently clear in the documentation, and which in turn can lead to confusing dependency issues when both approaches are used within the same application (or across different libraries which are consumed by that application):

## Service "Ownership" ##
If `MyService` is configured for injection using the `@NgModule` `providers` decoration, the service can rightly be considered to "belong" to that NgModule. It is also therefore that module's responsibility to make sure that it imports any other NgModules which provide services that `MyService` depends on.

If `MyService` is configured using the `@Injectable`, `providedIn: 'root'` syntax though, the service no longer really "belongs" anywhere. It might be co-located with a particular NgModule on the file system, but it has no relationship to it - it doesn't know about the module, and the module doesn't know about the service. This may not be immediately obvious to developers.

Because there is no longer an "owning" NgModule, the `MyService` class will now just be bundled with whatever consumes it, and it is then the _consumer's_ responsibility to ensure that the service's dependencies - i.e. any services which are injected into it - are available. This is fine if all _those_ services have also been configured with `providedIn: 'root'` (and also all of _their_ dependencies, etc.). It becomes more complicated though, in a scenario where interdependencies exist between services that have been configured in different ways - as can easily happen when using third party libraries, or even when consuming built-in Angular services that have been configured via the old-style `providers` array.

## Problem Example ###
Consider the following scenario:

1.  `MyComponent` is in `MyComponentModule` and consumes `MyService` which has been decorated with `providedIn: 'root'`. `MyService` is "in" (but not really - it is just co-located with) `MyServiceModule`.
2.  `MyService` consumes `ThirdPartyService` _which hasn't been similarly decorated_. Instead, `ThirdPartyService` has been provided via the `providers` array in `ThirdPartyServiceModule`.
3. `MyServiceModule` imports `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but as it turns out this is incidental, because _`MyService` doesn't really belong to `MyServiceModule`_

The code fails at run time, when it attempts to instantiate `MyService` for injection into `MyComponent` with:
```
NullInjectorError: No provider for ThirdPartyService!
```

This is because `MyComponentModule` has not imported `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but this is not very obvious to the developer. It doesn't seem very logical (to me anyway) that `MyComponentModule` should have to care about `MyService`'s dependencies (or perhaps even its dependencies' dependencies), just because of the different ways in which these services have been configured.

As I say, I don't really know what the best way is to fix this - apart from perhaps making the implications of all this a little clearer in the documentation. The cat is now somewhat out of the bag regarding the (now not-so-)new `providedIn: 'root'` syntax and at the moment I can't think of a way to make these 2 different approaches play nicely with each other.

### Description

There are some situation that we want to update to specific version, to not latest angular version.

But, there are no description for how to update to specific angular version with `ng update` in [update.angular.io](https://update.angular.io/) and [ng update reference](https://angular.io/cli/update). Caution: not "migrate only update". I refer about update the installed version.

By the way, Acording to [angular-cli/docs/specifications/update.md](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/v8.0.4/docs/specifications/update.md) ,

> Each package follows the convention of [@scope/]packageName[@version-range-or-dist-tag]. 

So we can use next command to update specific Angular version.

```
ng update @angular/cli@7.0.0 @angular/core@7.0.0
```

Is this above method that update to specific version is defined correctly?
And this is a little hard to find how to update to specific version.
I am so happy if there is documented at [update.angular.io](https://update.angular.io/) or [ng update reference](https://angular.io/cli/update).

related : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52970467/ng-update-to-specific-angular-version

### Describe the solution you'd like

How about documenting how to update to specific angular version with `ng update` in [update.angular.io](https://update.angular.io/) and [ng update reference](https://angular.io/cli/update)?

```
ng update @angular/cli@7.0.0 @angular/core@7.0.0
```

**Webpage**: [HostListener](https://angular.io/api/core/HostListener)

**Issue**
I'd consider myself barely an adept at Angular, but it wasn't too long ago since I was a complete novice. I found that certain areas of the Angular documentation are very uninformative (_perhaps I am not reading them correctly?_). 

For example the HostListener section of the documentation does not cover what type of events are covered or how to call them. I personally found the explanation of the method a bit brief. I have found in other sections as well that it is often assumes that the reader has a certain level of understanding of Angular instead of endeavouring to be as informative and in depth as possible. This has led to lengthy discussions online and searches outside of the [Angular](https://angular.io/) website as well beginners lacking an understanding of the possibilities and scope for the method's application.

I would appreciate that (and I am sure so would many other developers) cited complex as well as simple examples of the method's application would be given. Thank you.

# üêû bug report
### Is this a regression?
Yes, it wasn't present in the latest 7 release (see below)

### Description
https://angular.io/guide/testing#support-more-macrotasks describes a way to support more macro tasks, the Canvas example is even used in the sample app that you can download at the top of that same page (source code: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/examples/testing/src/app/shared/canvas.component.spec.ts).

I noticed that the example app doesn't allow to run `ng test` (due to missing tsconfig file), so I was working on fixing that in order to send in PR to patch it. Once I managed to run `ng test` successfully (as in: the tests are extecuted), I noticed that 3 tests failed. I fixed 2 of them (we can discuss the reasons of their failure in the PR once it's up as I think it's unrelated to what I'll be describing here), but I can't seem to resolve the 3th test (which I will describe in the reproduction steps below). I noticed that the code to support the macro tasks isn't working properly anymore.

I'm not sure this is an issue with Angular or an issue with ZoneJS. Maybe it's not even an issue and we can fix this easily by updating the docs' tests. In that case I'll be happy to fix it as part of the PR I'm finishing.

As I noticed @JiaLiPassion created this test initially (https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/21669), and, if I remember correctly, also added this functionality into zonejs, I wanted to check if you might have any idea what has been changed in zonejs that would break this test?


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction (issue in the docs)
- Open the Angular repo locally
- checkout master
- cd into aio and run `yarn build`
- cd into `aio/content/examples/testing` and run `yarn test`

3 tests should fail. You can ignore the `No test scheduler initialized` for now, I've managed to resolve this locally by patching the exampleZipper but this issue is only about the one that's failing with the following message:
```
chrome 74.0.3729 (Linux 0.0.0) CanvasComponent should be able to generate blob data from canvas FAILED
    Error: Expected undefined to be greater than 0.
        at <Jasmine>
        at UserContext.<anonymous> (src/app/shared/canvas.component.spec.ts:24:26)
        at UserContext.<anonymous> (home/frederik/Development/github/frederikprijck/angular/aio/tools/examples/shared/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:1493:1)
        at ZoneDelegate.invoke (home/frederik/Development/github/frederikprijck/angular/aio/tools/examples/shared/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:359:1)
```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction (underlying issue isolated from the docs)
As it was easier for me to swap dependency versions to find the issue, I isolated the issue in an empty cli project:
- Create a new @angular/cli 8 project
- Add this component https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/examples/testing/src/app/shared/canvas.component.ts and this test https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/examples/testing/src/app/shared/canvas.component.spec.ts to the project
- run `ng test`

The tests should fail with:
```
chrome 74.0.3729 (Linux 0.0.0) CanvasComponent should be able to generate blob data from canvas FAILED
    Error: Expected undefined to be greater than 0.
        at <Jasmine>
        at UserContext.<anonymous> (src/app/shared/canvas.component.spec.ts:24:26)
        at UserContext.<anonymous> (home/frederik/Development/github/frederikprijck/angular/aio/tools/examples/shared/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:1493:1)
        at ZoneDelegate.invoke (home/frederik/Development/github/frederikprijck/angular/aio/tools/examples/shared/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:359:1)
```
If we do the same, but for an @angular/cli 7 project, the test works fine.
Once we upgrade `zone` to `0.9.1` (which is the version used when using `@angular/cli` 8) in an Angular 7 project, the tests fail. 

It's also broken with zone.js `0.9.0` but works fine with `0.8.29`.

This might be a regression in zonejs, however I'm not that familiar with zonejs so I was hoping to hear @JiaLiPassion 's opinion on this.

## üî• Exception or Error
Test is not succeeding.

## üåç  Your Environment
I've tested this with Angular 7 and 8, on Linux (Elementary OS) and Windows 10.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> The docs / style guide should provide a guide / example for partially shared lazy feature modules.
At the moment there's only the [Sharing Modules](https://angular.io/guide/sharing-ngmodules) guide for _"**commonly** used directives, pipes, and components"_.
But there should be another guide that focuses on sharing _"**un**commenly used components"_. (Or: _"lazy loaded modules that depend on **some** components of other lazy loaded modules"_)

### Example 1:
I have an enterprise application with lot's of modules, which are all lazy loaded. But some of these modules use a few components and services of other modules. 
```
app/
    module1/
        components/
            M1Component1
            M1Component2 <-- uses M1Component1 internally. no problem because it's the same module

    module2/
            M2Component1 <-- uses M1Component1 internally
```
What's the best way to solve this? Putting these components into `SharedModule` isn't an option, because those components aren't _"**commonly** used"_. And importing the whole `Module1` into `Module2` isn't an either, because I only need a few components from `Module1`.

### Example 2:
The application has a `DashboardModule` which uses `InjectionToken` and `Provider`s to register `WidgetComponent`s from other modules. Those `Providers` must be registered at application start (or when the `DashboardModule` gets loaded).
In other words: The `DashboardModule` doesn't know any widgets by itself. All widgets are provided by the other modules. But all those modules are lazy loaded.
```
app/
    dashboard/
        services/
            DashboardWidgetTypeService <-- with @Inject(DASHBOARD_WIDGET) widgets

    module1/ <-- provides M1DashboardComponent as DASHBOARD_WIDGET
        components/
            M1DashboardComponent

    module2/ <-- provides M2DashboardComponent as DASHBOARD_WIDGET
        components/
            M2DashboardComponent
```

### Current Solution:
<!-- If applicable please describe the difference between the expected and actual behavior after following the repro steps. -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:-->

At the moment each module consists of 2 modules: a `SharedFeatureModule` and a `FeatureModule`. And the `AppModule` imports all those `SharedFeatureModule`s.
```
app/
    module1/
        MyFeature1Module <-- imports MyFeature1RoutingModule and MyFeature1SharedModule
        MyFeature1RoutingModule
        MyFeature1SharedModule <-- has forRoot method to register Dashboard providers

    module2/
        MyFeature2Module <-- imports MyFeature2RoutingModule and MyFeature2SharedModule and MyFeature1SharedModule
        MyFeature2RoutingModule
        MyFeature2SharedModule <-- has forRoot method to register Dashboard providers

    AppModule <-- imports MyFeature1SharedModule.forRoot() and MyFeature2SharedModule.forRoot()
```
The `AppModule` imports all `SharedFeatureModule`s via `forRoot()` to register the dashboard widget providers.

I'm not yet sure what's the "best practice" for this. But I'm sure you'll have some good advice.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
From https://next.angular.io/guide/static-query-migration:

> Without the static flag, the compiler decided when each query would be resolved on a case-by-case basis. All @ViewChild/@ContentChild queries were categorized into one of two buckets at compile time: "static" or "dynamic".

But now we have to define this, and this is cool with me, but what if my code relied on a Query which, in one case, needs to be dynamic, and in another case, needs to be static?

Example:
- I have a base_validation component, which gets specialized in input_validation, select_validation, etc...
- The base_validation component keeps a link on a generic NgModel declared in each of the specialized components
- In "input_validation", the NgModel must be resolved statically
- In "select_validation", the NgModel must be resolved dynamically (i have to do some *ngIf magic there)

After fiddling with this for some time i found a way to make the new ViewChild act exactly like the previous version so that component logic refactoring will not (as far as my tests go) be required.

(Apparently i'm unable to format this decently...)

@ViewChild(NgModel, { static: false }) validationControl: NgModel;

@ViewChild(NgModel, { static: true }) set validationControl_static(comp: NgModel) {
    if (comp) { this.validationControl = comp; }
};

This way, apparently, you get the dynamic part of the ViewChild and you "manually" merge it with the static part. (also, setters on a dynamic ViewChild doesn't get fired for some reason).

I think this might be useful to add to the static-query-migration. At least it would have been useful for me :)

Cheers!

# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/.... ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description My website used to run on https://jobs.af, after four months we appended the www -> https://www.jobs.af. The thing we did not think about was that service workers don‚Äôt play nice with redirects What we didn't pay attention to is that service workers do not play nice with redirects The user would go to https://www.jobs.af and NGINX would send them a 301 redirect for every resource they‚Äôd send a request for. This worked perfectly fine for new users, but users who had already visited the website would encounter some issues. Service workers update themselves automatically if there‚Äôs a new version available. In our case it tried to get the new version on https://www.jobs.af/ngsw-worker.js, which redirects to https://jobs.af/ngsw-worker.js. So the service worker would try to update itself from a new service worker behind a redirect which caused the following error: enter image description here My Code: `app.browser.module.ts` ``` @NgModule({ imports: [ BrowserModule.withServerTransition({ appId: "app-root" }), . . . # üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

## Description
I wanted to know how Injectable worked and whether or not we are actually required to use it (not that I want to omit it, just as a matter of understanding how things work).

At first, I thought Injectable was always required for any service that's used (either by adding it to the providers or using providedIn, which requires Injectable anyway) in Angular.

However, we noticed that Injectable is only required to be used as a decorator on a service that has dependencies which are being injected into its constructor.

This was easily verified using a Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-pgkrb5

- If you would omit the @Injectable from `FooService`, it'll show an error: `Can't resolve all parameters for FooService: (?).`. 
- If you would inject BarService (which has no @Injectable) into the AppComponent, everything works fine as well.

However, doing some more testing it turns out we can replace the Injectable decorator with any other decorator, even the HostBinding works: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qkngb5

Doing some googling on this quickly showed me I wasn't the first one noticing this, so this is not really something new I guess.

However, in order to fully understand how it worked, I needed to fiddle with Stackblitz, the docs didn't really give me a proper answer. I found some things I wanted to update to be more accurate if anyone else ever would have the same question as I had.

As I don't think the above findings are things that necessarily need to end up in the docs, I thought I would be better of creating an issue first to discuss this further before creating a PR to update the docs.

## A few remarks on snippets from the docs
https://angular.io/api/core/Injectable

> Injector throws an error if it tries to instantiate a class that is not decorated with @Injectable, as shown in the following example.

I think this isn't entirely correct, it's only the case when that service has dependencies which are being injected in its constructor. 

https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services

> Notice that the Logger service also has the @Injectable() decorator, even though it might not need its own dependencies. In fact, the @Injectable() decorator is required for all services.

> When Angular creates a class whose constructor has parameters, it looks for type and injection metadata about those parameters so that it can inject the correct service. If Angular can't find that parameter information, it throws an error. Angular can only find the parameter information if the class has a decorator of some kind. The @Injectable() decorator is the standard decorator for service classes.

Both snippets above might be a bit contradicting, the first one mentions it's required for all services. While the second snippet is mentioning the fact that the class' constructor needs to have parameters.

## What I'd propose to change:

https://angular.io/api/core/Injectable:

> Injector throws an error if it tries to instantiate a class that is not decorated with @Injectable and is making use of Dependency Injection (add link to https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection or https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services here), as shown in the following example.

Maybe we can also include an example that shows it doesn't throw in case we omit Injectable and have no Dependency Injection.

https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services

> Notice that the Logger service also has the @Injectable() decorator, even though it might not need its own dependencies. Even though it's not required to add Injectable when you're not making use of Dependency Injection, we do encourage adding it as this will make it easier to add dependencies later on.

> When Angular creates a class whose constructor has parameters, it looks for type and injection metadata about those parameters so that it can inject the correct service. If Angular can't find that parameter information, it throws an error. Angular can only find the parameter information if the class has a decorator of some kind. The @Injectable() decorator is the standard decorator for service classes.

Even tho this still isn't 100% correct (as Injectable isn't required, any decorator should do), I think this could be an improvement.

I'm also not aware if Ivy would change anything with regards to this, if this is the case these changes might be obsolete.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The documentation on the complex sequences page has an error in it. https://angular.io/guide/complex-animation-sequences

In the first section *Animate multiple elements using query() and stagger() functions*, the text reads: "Use query() to look for any element entering or leaving the page."

The code example directly below this text follows:

```
animations: [
    trigger('pageAnimations', [
      transition(':enter', [
        query('.hero, form', [
          style({opacity: 0, transform: 'translateY(-100px)'}),
          stagger(-30, [
            animate('500ms cubic-bezier(0.35, 0, 0.25, 1)', style({ opacity: 1, transform: 'none' }))
          ])
        ])
      ])
    ]),
  ]
})

```
This code does not show the query function looking for elements entering and leaving the page: The query function is targeting elements *within* the element being animated which match the query '.hero, form'. i.e. are form elements or have the 'hero' class on them.

In the live example, there is also a `filterAnimation` trigger. This does show the query function looking for elements entering and leaving the page. This is probably what the example should show.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description For the section https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/guide/router.md#import-crisis-center-module-into-the-appmodule-routes in the router.md doc. The current text is: > Import crisis center module into the AppModule routes > As with the HeroesModule, you must add the CrisisCenterModule to the imports array of the AppModule before the AppRoutingModule: The **placement** order in the **imports array of the AppModule** shall be highlighted with a Notice or Warning, since the natural way of doing the hero tutorial is adding the crisis-center module with the crisis-center routing using the angular-cli after the app module. The angular-cli creates the import of crisis-center module after the AppRoutingModule. This will be an issue for the code. When a **Wildcard route** is defined in the **AppRoutingModule**, the wildcard route will be matched before the child route in the crisis-center routing can be matched. This happens very often wenn using the angular-cli to added submodule with routing feature. The natrual way of adding Wildcard route is in the AppRoutingModule, and then always place the AppRoutingModule after all submodule in the import array of the AppModule. The debugging of such error relating to the routes match due to the import placement order is very difficult. Thus, i suggest to improve the original doc text to hightlight this issue to prevent error in coding and improve the readers understanding of the impact of the placement order in the imports array of the angular modules. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/guide/router#import-crisis-center-module-into-the-appmodule-routes ### Reproduction Steps** ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
